newsitem.title: USA: Clinton is avoiding debates - Dole campaign chief.
newsitem.headline: Clinton is avoiding debates - Dole campaign chief.

text.p: Republican Bob Dole's campaign manager, Scott Reed, accused President Clinton Thursday of wanting to have the fewest possible presidential debates in front of the smallest possible audience.

The accusation, in a letter to Clinton campaign manager Peter Knight, came as the two sides continued to squabble over minor details of the debates, the first of which is scheduled for Oct. 6 in Hartford, Connecticut.
"We know President Clinton's highest priority is to have the least number of debates before the smallest possible audience," Reed wrote.
The Dole campaign wants to move up the time of the second debate, scheduled for Oct. 16 in San Diego, by 45 minutes to avoid clashing with a baseball playoff game.

The Dole team also wants the candidates to stand behind a "writing platform" to accomodate Dole, who has difficulty taking notes because of a war wound. The San Diego debate is planned as a "town hall meeting" where the candidates answer questions from undecided voters.
Reed accused Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, the head of the Clinton debate negotiating team, of "arrogance and deceitfulness" in refusing to accomodate Dole's request.
But Clinton campaign spokesman Joe Lockhart said the Dole team was trying to change the deal the sides made last weekend when they agreed on the debates.
"As soon as we open up the deal, we're going to find 10 more demands from their side. Right now we're wondering if they really want a debate," he said.
"If they want to formally reopen negotiations, they should come out and say so. Writing an obnoxious letter is not going to get anyone anywhere," Lockhart said.

As far as the desk is concerned, Lockhart said the parties had agreed that the bipartisan commission on presidential debates would design a three-sided writing structure, which both campaigns then had the right to approve.
The clash was seen as unlikely to derail the debates.
Clinton, campaigning in Philadelphia, told reporters later Wednesday he was certain the debates would take place.
"There'll be debates. I'm sure there will," he said.
